bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Josephine Ames Morris, July 21, 1942

div1.p: Hench describes his research on the conquest of yellow fever. He is anxious to learn as much as possible about Ames' contribution.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Josephine Ames Morris, July 21, 1942
div1.opener:
July 21, 1942
Mrs. Will Morris
515 Adams Street
New Orleans, La.
My dear Mrs. Morris:
div1.p:
I understand that you are the sister of Dr. Roger Post Ames. For
several years now I have been making quite a study of the conquest of yellow
fever particularly the work of the army yellow fever commission in Havana in
1900. As a result of these investigations I have uncovered much new informa-
tion which I expect to publish in a few articles in medical historical journals
and probably in a book. I have received much information from the relatives of
Dr. Walter Reed, Dr. Lazear, Dr. Agramonte and others. Permit me to send you
three reprints of an article, published in a recent issue of a medical journal.
I thought you might like to have one for yourself and perhaps a couple for others
of Dr. Ames' close relatives. Should you wish more, I should be delighted to
send them to you.

I am anxious to learn as much as I can about Dr. Ames' contribution to
the yellow fever problem. According to one view, Dr. Ames actually lived at
Camp Lazear and was Executive Officer there and also took care of all of the
cases of experimental yellow fever. Mr. Moran, one of the first cases of experi-
mental yellow fever, whom I personally visited, does not remember that Dr. Ames
actually lived at the camp. However, Mr. Gust Lambert of Chicago, who nursed his
cases for Dr. Ames, insists that he was. I am inclined to feel that Mr. Moran's
memory is at fault on this point.

Do you have any of Dr. Ames' records, any photographs or clippings or
other data of Dr. Ames in connection with the yellow fever experiments? I should
be so grateful if you would let me know what you have and if you would lend these
to me, sending them to me either by insured express or by insured registered mail.
I should be delighted to pay all shipping expenses and will assure you that they
will be returned promptly and safely. I have already thus borrowed considerable
material from other relatives of the yellow fever investigators and with their
permission have had the material photostated, photographed and copied here. It
is my hope not only to use these data to complete the full picture of Dr. Ames'
contribution but also to exhibit the copies of your data in a little historical
medical museum which I am planning to erect on the rediscovered site of Camp
Lazear in Havana, Cuba.

Fairly soon I expect to enter military service. I would appreciate it
greatly if you would therefore let me know at your earliest convenience if you
have anything so that I can arrange to study it and have it copied here before
I leave for army service.
div1.closer: Very truly yours, P. S. Hench, M. D. psh:ds
